images.summary: This image shows a building section cut from rear to front, illustrating multiple levels of the structure. Key components include engineered roof trusses, a hollow-core floor, and a concrete foundation. The section details typical exterior 2x6 stud walls with prefinished siding and a precast concrete balcony supported by a dropped wood beam. The foundation includes a concrete floor slab on spray foam and clear stone, with stepped footings and rigid insulation extending 48 inches on each side. Elevations are marked for the top of the wall bearing plate at the main floor (108'-1"), top of the subfloor at the main floor (102'-0"), and top of the wall bearing plate at the basement (99'-4"). The section is drawn at a scale of 3/16"=1'-0".

images.summary: This detail illustrates a concrete lintel at a brick ledge, showing reinforcement and construction specifics. The lintel accommodates furring under siding and includes (2) 15M rebar placed 2 inches from the top and bottom of the wall, with 10M stirrups at 6 inches on center. The concrete foundation is 12 inches thick with a 25 MPa strength and a 4-inch brick ledge, reinforced with 15M vertical and horizontal bars at 24 inches on center. The section is drawn at a scale of 1/2" = 1'-0".

images.summary: This elevation view shows a concrete lintel with detailed reinforcement specifications. The lintel is reinforced with (2) 15M rebar placed 2 inches from the top and bottom of the wall, and 10M stirrups at 6 feet on center. A steel lintel is specified as per plan, and the concrete lintel is to be removed, keeping the bars around the window. The opening is a maximum of 6'-0". The elevation is drawn at a scale of 1/2" = 1'-0".

images.summary: This image provides detailed notes on various wall types and their specifications. It includes descriptions of exterior basement foundation walls, which feature drainage layers, asphaltic dampproofing, and concrete foundations with reinforcement. The exterior brick basement foundation wall includes brick veneer with galvanized brick ties and solid grout fill. The typical exterior porch foundation wall is a 10-inch concrete foundation with 2-15M rebar at the top. Upper-level exterior walls include brick veneer and siding options, both with insulation, sheathing, and gypsum board. Interior party walls and firewalls are described with gypsum board, wood studs, and mineral fiber insulation, offering fire resistance ratings and sound transmission class values.

images.summary: This image provides an index to the drawings included in the set. It lists ten pages, starting with the cover page, Ontario Building Code requirements, construction schedule, and building section. Subsequent pages include front and right elevations, rear and left elevations, foundation plan, basement floor plan, main floor plan, roof framing plan, wall sections, hollow core and shear wall details, and details with structural notes. This index serves as a guide to navigate the comprehensive set of drawings for the project.

ROOF TYPES
TYPICAL ROOF WITH ATTIC SPACE
-GAF-TIMBERLINE FIBREGLASS/ASPHALT SHINGLES
-36" WIDE EAVE PROTECTION (MIN. 12" INSIDE INNER WALL FACE)
-36" WIDE VALLEY FLASHING
-ROOF VENTS WITH UNOBSTRUCTED AREA OF 1/300 OF INSUL. AREA
-7/16" O.S.B.
-INSULATION BAFFLES AND RAFTER VENTS
-RAF. AND CEILING JOIST (SEE PLAN FOR SIZE AND SPACING) or ENGIN. TRUSSES c/w 'H' CLIPS
-R60 INSULATION (MINIMUM 10" HEAL HEIGHT)
-6 MIL POLY VAPOUR BARRIER
-1/2" CONTROLLED DENSITY BOARD
images.summary: This detail illustrates a typical roof with attic space, highlighting various components and materials used. The roof is covered with GAF-Timberline fibreglass/asphalt shingles. Eave protection is 36 inches wide, extending a minimum of 12 inches inside the inner wall face. Valley flashing is also 36 inches wide. Roof vents are designed to provide an unobstructed area of 1/300 of the insulation area. The roof structure includes 7/16 inch O.S.B., insulation baffles, and rafter vents. Rafters and ceiling joists are specified, with the option for engineered trusses complete with 'H' clips. The insulation is R60, with a minimum 10-inch heel height. A 6 mil poly vapour barrier and 1/2 inch controlled density board complete the assembly.

images.summary: This elevation view shows the front facade of a 14-unit stacked townhouse project. Each unit features a combination of prefinished aluminum capped beams, horizontal siding, precast balconies, and brick veneer. The windows are primarily casement style, with dimensions such as 50"(18"x32") x36" and 60"(36"x24") x24". Entry doors are 36" x 6'-8". The elevation indicates various levels, including the top of wall bearing plate at 128'-1", main floor at 120'-0", basement wall at 99'-4", and basement floor at 89'-9". Concrete footings support the structure, and there are sunken entries. The drawing provides a detailed view of the architectural and structural elements of the front facade.

NOTE:
PREFIN. RAILING and CONNECTIONS BY OTHERS. SUBMIT P.ENG. STAMPED SHOP DRAWINGS TO EOR FOR REVIEW (TYP.)

NOTE:
FOR RAINWATER DISCHARGE, REFER TO MUNICIPAL REQUIREMENTS

NOTE:
ALL STAIR, RAMPS, HANDRAILS AND GUARDS SHALL CONFORM TO O.B.C. 9.8. AND THE SUPPLEMENTARY STANDARDS SBT

NOTE:
EVERY WINDOW WELL SHALL BE DRAINED TO THE FOOTING LEVEL OR OTHER SUITABLE LOCATION AS PER O.B.C. 9.14.6.3.

NOTE:
EXTERIOR LIGHTING MUST BE INSTALLED AT EVERY ENTRANCE TO BUILDINGS OF RESIDENTIAL OCCUPANCY AS PER O.B.C. 9.34.2.1

NOTE:
IF THE BOTTOM EDGE OF THE OPENABLE PORTION OF A WINDOW IS LESS THAN 900mm (35 1/2") ABOVE FINISHED FLOOR LEVEL AND MORE THAN 1800mm (5'-11") ABOVE FINISHED GROUND LEVEL, IT SHALL BE PROTECTED BY A MECHANISM THAT LIMITS THE OPERATION TO A MAX. DISTANCE OF 100mm (4'), AS PER O.B.C. 9.8.8.1.
images.summary: This image contains general notes related to construction requirements. Key points include the need for prefabricated railings and connections to be submitted with P.Eng. stamped shop drawings for review. Rainwater discharge must comply with municipal requirements. Stairs, ramps, handrails, and guards must conform to O.B.C. 9.8 and supplementary standards SBT. Window wells should be drained to the footing level as per O.B.C. 9.14.6.3. Exterior lighting is required at every entrance for residential buildings according to O.B.C. 9.34.2.1. Windows with a bottom edge less than 900mm above the floor and more than 1800mm above ground must be limited in operation to 100mm as per O.B.C. 9.8.8.1.

ELEV. 99'-4" (TOP OF FOUNDATION) IS EQUAL TO GEODETIC ELEVATION 208.41 m
ELEV. 89'-9" (BASEMENT FLOOR) IS EQUAL TO GEODETIC ELEVATION 205.49 m

ELEVATION NOTE
TOP OF FINISHED MAIN FLOOR ELEVATION IS REFERENCED TO 100'-0"(IMPERIAL) FOR FOUNDATION AND FOOTING ELEVATIONS SHOWN.

ELEVATION NOTE
TOP OF FOUNDATION WALL ELEVATIONS SHOWN THUS: 99'-4"
TOP OF FOOTING ELEVATIONS SHOWN THUS: 89'-6"

FW - APPROXIMATE LOCATION OF STEP IN FOUNDATION WALL
FS - APPROXIMATE LOCATION OF STEP IN FOOTING

FOUNDATION NOTES
1) STEPS IN FOUNDATION WALLS AND FOOTINGS ARE TO BE SITE VERIFIED.
2) STEP FOOTINGS NOT TO EXCEED 23 5/8".
3) STEP FOOTINGS NOT INDICATED MAY BE REQUIRED IF ADVERSE SOIL CONDITIONS ARE PRESENT.

TYPICAL PORCH WALL:
10" THICK CONCRETE, 25 MPa w/ (2) 15M HORIZONTAL at TOP OF WALL

TYPICAL EXTERIOR BASEMENT WALL:
12" or 8" THICK CONCRETE, 25 MPa r/w 15M VERTICAL at 24" o.c. AND 15M HORIZONTAL at 24 o.c. PLUS 1-15M HORIZ. UNDER BRICK LEDGE WHERE APPLICABLE. (SEE WALL SECTION ON PAGE 8)

NOTE:
FOOTINGS and FOUNDATION WALLS CONNECTED w/ 15M x 24" LONG DOWEL at 24" o.c. w/ 6" EMBEDMENT INTO FOOTING

NOTE:
UNLESS OTHERWISE INDICATED, FOOTINGS ARE MIN. 24" WIDE x 8" DEEP WITH TWO (2) ROWS 15M REBAR CONTINUOUS.
images.summary: This image provides foundation notes and elevation details for the building. The top of the foundation is at elevation 99'-4", equivalent to a geodetic elevation of 208.41 m, while the basement floor is at 89'-9", equivalent to 205.49 m. The top of the finished main floor elevation is referenced to 100'-0" imperial. Foundation wall and footing elevations are shown as 99'-4" and 89'-6", respectively. Steps in foundation walls and footings must be site verified, with step footings not exceeding 23 5/8". Typical porch walls are 10" thick concrete with 25 MPa strength and two 15M horizontal bars at the top. Exterior basement walls are 12" or 8" thick concrete with 25 MPa strength, 15M vertical bars at 24" o.c., and additional horizontal reinforcement. Footings and foundation walls are connected with 15M x 24" dowels at 24" o.c. with 6" embedment. Unless otherwise indicated, footings are a minimum of 24" wide x 8" deep with continuous 15M rebar.

images.summary: This foundation plan outlines the layout and specifications for the building's foundation, including concrete walls and footings. It includes a buck out window/door schedule with sizes to be determined by the window supplier. Specific buck outs include W1 for a 5'-0" patio door with a 16" transom at elevation 89'-9", W2 for a 56"x 36" horizontal sliding window at elevation 97'-3", W3 for a 50"x 36" combo casement at elevation 97'-9", W4 for a 36"x 6'-8" entry door at elevation 89'-9", and W5 for a 60"x 24" combo casement at elevation 97'-9". All openings have reinforced concrete lintels as referenced on page 1. The plan ensures stability and compliance with structural requirements, detailing material strengths and construction depths.

images.summary: This section view shows the rear balcony at the side wall, focusing on the structural components and connections. The section includes a steel beam as per plan, precast concrete with a bottom flange, and semi-rigid mineral wool in a 1" space. A 3 1/2" curb is detailed, and the precast designer must confirm adequate bearing. A 1/2" thick plate provides additional bearing as required, with a minimum 6" bearing at each end using a 6"x6"x1/2" bearing plate and a 15M x24" dowel wet set into the wall. Wood under-framing supports the structure, and a patio door opening is indicated. The section is labeled as '2 REAR BALCONY at SIDE WALL' with a scale of 1/2"=1'-0".

images.summary: This image shows a lintel and post schedule for the basement level. The lintel schedule includes wood lintels labeled L1 to L4, with dimensions ranging from 2x6 to 2x12, and a steel lintel labeled L5 with dimensions 3 1/2" x 3 1/2" x 1/4". The post schedule includes P.T. posts labeled P1 and P2, which are wrapped and require fastening beams with Simpson AC6 pairs. The posts are anchored to hollow-core with ABU66Z or ABU88Z and ATR 5/8 x 6"lg threaded rods, using AT3G10 adhesive or an approved equivalent. P3 specifies a hanger, HUC210-3, with the 4th ply able to lap the hanger flange.

images.summary: This detail shows a side bearing connection for the basement level. The precast element is notched and grouted locally, with weldable 10M bars specified at 1'-4" long at 6'-0" on center. The precast extends 1" past the quarter point of the beam to prevent twisting of the steel support. Grout joints are solid, and additional weldable 10M bars are 3'-0" long at each grout joint. A drypack or steel shim void is indicated, to be provided by others. An additional detail is required for bars connected to the precast and welded to the bottom of the beam top flange.

images.summary: This image contains general notes for the basement level. It specifies that Sonopan is to be used on the interior of all mechanical room walls, and all stairs must have a 10" run with an 11" tread throughout. Interior walls are to be framed with 2x4 studs unless noted otherwise. Prefinished railings and connections are by others, with P.Eng. stamped shop drawings required for review by the Engineer of Record (EOR). Pressure-treated (P.T.) ratings are provided for decking (UC3.2B), ledger boards, joists, beams, stair stringers (UC3.2C), and posts (UC4.1D). Members in unconditioned spaces not directly exposed to elements may remain untreated, though wood condition and aesthetics may degrade over time.

images.summary: This section view illustrates a 2-hour firewall designed per ULC W314, SA-925 CGC standards. The wall comprises multiple layers, including 1/2" regular gypsum board, OSB sheathing, and mineral fiber insulation, fitted into metal 'H' studs. Fire stop caulking is installed on both sides of the wall to enhance fire resistance. The wall is anchored to a concrete strip footing with 5/8" x 6" expansion anchors. A 3" concrete floor slab with rigid spray foam insulation acts as a radon barrier. The top plates are anchored to hollow-core slabs with threaded rods. The section ensures compliance with fire safety standards and structural integrity.

images.summary: This section view illustrates the construction details of a left and right side exterior wall with end bearing. The wall includes truss lateral braces installed as directed by the engineer, with insulation baffles typical at each rafter space. The roof features R60 insulation with a minimum 10-inch heel height, and an aluminum eavetrough on a 2x6 aluminum clad fascia. The wall is constructed with a continuous vented soffit on J-mould and prefinished horizontal siding on 1x4 furring strips. The wall assembly includes a 6 mil poly air/vapor barrier, a double top plate, and a lintel built out to 5-1/2 inches wide with blocking for insulation. The interior features 1/2-inch gypsum board over a 6 mil poly vapor barrier on 2x6 wood stud framing at 16 inches on center with R22 fiberglass batt insulation. The sill plate is anchored to the hollow-core with a 5/8-inch diameter threaded rod at 48 inches on center, with a minimum 6-inch embedment at the center of cores, fastened with Hilti HIT-HY 200-V or equivalent. The foundation consists of an 8-inch thick concrete foundation with 25 MPa strength, reinforced with 15M vertical and horizontal rebar at 24 inches on center. The footing is a 30-inch wide by 10-inch deep concrete strip footing with continuous 15M rebar. The system includes asphaltic damp-proofing up to the finished grade and flexible sealant at the base. The section also details the use of 2x4 wood strapping set 1 inch off the wall with 4 1/2-inch R21 spray foam insulation and gypsum board. The floor slab is a 3-inch concrete slab on 2-inch R12 spray foam insulation, serving as a radon barrier, over a minimum of 5 inches of clean granular material.

images.summary: This section view shows a typical 1-hour fire-rated party wall. The roof construction includes GAF-Timberline fiberglass/asphalt shingles on 7/16-inch OSB sheathing with 'H' clips on pre-engineered roof trusses at 24 inches on center. The wall assembly consists of 5/8-inch Type X gypsum board on each finished side of two rows of 2x4 wood studs at 16 inches on center, staggered on separate bottom plates set 1 inch apart. The wall includes sound absorption insulation in the stud spaces on each side, with a fire resistance rating of 1 hour and a sound transmission class of 51. A 6 mil poly vapor barrier is provided on one side of the wall behind the gypsum board. The air space is filled with semi-rigid Roxall 'Cavity Rock' mineral wool insulation at the ceiling level for fire stopping. The foundation includes a 3-inch concrete floor slab on 2-inch R12 spray foam insulation, serving as a radon barrier, over a minimum of 5 inches of clean granular material. The strip footing is 24 inches wide by 8 inches deep, reinforced with continuous 15M rebar. The bottom plates are anchored to the strip footing with 5/8-inch by 6-inch expansion anchors at 24 inches on center. The section also details dowels across the party wall and solid cores filled at the plant.

2x4 STRUT x 5'-0" LONG @ TOP & BOTTOM WITH (2) 3-1/2" NAILS @ EACH TRUSS WEB MEMBER
2x4 DIAGONAL "X" BRACE ON OPPOSITE SIDE OF TRUSS AT ENDWALLS & WHERE SPECIFIED ELSEWHERE
ANCHOR 2x4 DIAGONAL "X" ON OPPOSITE SIDE OF WEB WITH (2) 3-1/2" NAILS @ EACH TRUSS
ANCHOR DIAGONAL BRACE TO STRUT @ BOTH ENDS WITH (4) 3-1/2" NAILS
TRUSS TOP CHORD
TRUSS WEB MEMBER
TRUSS BOTTOM CHORD
BUTT 2x4 LATERALS @ ALL SPLICE LOCATIONS. ENSURE BUTT JOINT IS TIGHT & CENTERED ON TRUSS WEB.
LAP 2x4 DIAGONAL (MIN. 2 TRUSSES) TO ENSURE DIAGONAL BRACE EXTENDS COMPLETELY FROM TOP CHORD TO BOTTOM CHORD OF TRUSS. (AS REQUIRED)
2x4 DIAGONAL BRACING SPACED AS REQUIRED BY THE BRACING DESIGNER
ROOF TRUSS BRACING NOTES
1. CONTRACTOR AND/OR OWNER TO NOTIFY MANUFACTURER OF ANY TRUSS DEFICIENCIES SUCH AS DAMAGED OR BROKEN TRUSSES, WARPING OF TRUSS MEMBERS, AND MISSING OR OFFSET TRUSS PLATES.
2. DIAGONAL BRACING MUST BE PROVIDED ON ALL WEB MEMBERS THAT REQUIRE LATERAL BRACING. DIAGONAL BRACING SHALL BE SPACED AS NOTED ON THE ATTACHED DRAWINGS. X-BRACING SHALL BE PROVIDED AT ENDWALL AND AT INTERVALS NOTED ON THE ROOF PLAN.
3. PERMANENT LATERAL BRACING TO BE INSTALLED ON WEB MEMBERS AS INDICATED ON THE ROOF PLAN AND MANUFACTURERS DRAWINGS.
4. PROVIDE DIAGONAL BRACING AT ALL DISCONTINUITIES IN LATERAL BRACING SUCH AS WHERE TRUSS TYPE CHANGES. THE TRUSS SUPPLIER SHALL DESIGN THE TRUSSES FOR THE BRACING NOTED. BRACING DETAILS WILL NOT BE MODIFIED UNLESS SPECIFIED BY THE BUILDING DESIGNER.
5. TRUSS SUPPLIER WILL DESIGN TRUSSES FOR BRACING NOTED. BRACING DETAILS WILL NOT BE MODIFIED UNLESS SPECIFIED BY THE BUILDING DESIGNER.

images.summary: This truss bracing detail provides specifications for the installation of diagonal bracing on trusses. Strapping or sheathing on the roof deck is spaced as specified by the truss engineer. A 2x4 strut, 5'-0" long, is placed at the top and bottom with two 3-1/2" nails at each truss web member. Diagonal "X" bracing is anchored on the opposite side of the truss at endwalls and other specified locations, using two 3-1/2" nails at each truss. The diagonal brace is anchored to the strut at both ends with four 3-1/2" nails. The notes emphasize the importance of notifying the manufacturer of any truss deficiencies and ensuring diagonal bracing is provided on all web members requiring lateral bracing. The truss supplier is responsible for designing the trusses for the specified bracing, with no modifications unless specified by the building designer. The detail is labeled as typical (TYP.) and not to scale (N.T.S.).
